claim: Positioning sets context; without deliberate context, innovative products are misunderstood.
rationale: Context transforms perception (Joshua Bell subway). Market choice triggers assumptions on competitors/features/pricing.

claim: Start positioning with happiest, best-fit customers—they reveal true value and competitors.
rationale: All-customer surveys muddy signals; raving fans show clear patterns to target.

claim: Identify competitive alternatives by asking what best customers would do if you didn't exist.
rationale: Alternatives include manual processes or doing nothing; uniqueness is relative to perceived alternatives.

claim: Map attributes to value via 'So what?' Feature → Benefit → Value.
rationale: Customers buy outcomes; value translation connects capabilities to goals.

claim: Choose a market category that centers your strengths; category triggers assumptions.
rationale: Declaring the right category makes value obvious and sets expected competitors/features.

claim: Target as narrowly as possible while meeting sales goals; broaden later from strength.
rationale: Narrow focus accelerates traction and word-of-mouth; broad targeting dilutes message.

claim: Use trends to add relevance only after declaring market category.
rationale: Trends without category create confusion; trend should reinforce positioning.

claim: Positioning needs cross-functional alignment led by business owner, not marketing alone.
rationale: Sales/product/CS all contribute; alignment prevents divergent execution.

claim: Trap: stuck on intended product when it has evolved (cake on a stick vs cake pop).
rationale: Internal view lags product evolution; customers see current reality.

claim: Trap: market shifted but positioning stayed the same.
rationale: Static positioning in dynamic markets makes products irrelevant despite unchanged product.

claim: Positioning statement templates are useless; they assume answers and block creativity.
rationale: Fill-in-the-blank statements reinforce status quo, not strategy.

claim: Creating a new category is hardest—requires big resources and patience; big players can swoop in.
rationale: Demand must be created, not captured; without resources, education exhausts you.

claim: 5 components in order: Competitive Alternatives → Unique Attributes → Value → Target Market → Market Category (+ optional Trends).
rationale: Alternatives define uniqueness; uniqueness drives value; value for specific targets guides category choice.

claim: Three positioning styles: Head to Head, Big Fish Small Pond, Create New Game.
rationale: Style choice depends on market maturity and resources; each has distinct risks.

claim: Big Fish Small Pond: dominate a niche where you are good enough generally and best at niche needs.
rationale: Fighting leaders head-on is unwinnable; niche domination builds defensibility and word-of-mouth.

claim: Weak positioning symptoms: prospect confusion, long cycles/low close, churn, price pressure.
rationale: Market doesn’t see value; sales spends time explaining basics.

claim: Constantly explaining how you're unlike expectations means wrong category.
rationale: Category triggers assumptions; mismatched assumptions force endless correction.

claim: Database → Data Warehouse repositioning: same product, different category, higher price and success.
rationale: In 'database' they were weak vs Oracle; in 'data warehouse' their analysis strength was obvious.

claim: Janna Systems narrowed to investment banks, revenue from $2M to $70M in 18 months; acquired for $1.7B.
rationale: Niche made relationship-model strength obvious; Big Fish Small Pond enabled premium pricing and growth.

claim: Arm & Hammer repositioned from baking to deodorizer, unlocking growth and brand extensions.
rationale: Letting go of historical positioning aligned with actual usage, driving sales.

claim: Clearpath repositioned 'robots' to 'self-driving vehicles for industry' to match mobility strengths.
rationale: Category shift aligned expectations, reducing explanation and boosting sales.

claim: Long Blockchain: trend-only rebrand without substance caused spike then delisting.
rationale: Trend without product alignment creates hype then collapse; trends must reinforce value.

claim: Redgate layered DevOps trend onto 'database tools', doubling inbound leads.
rationale: Trend layering on clear category elevated urgency without changing core positioning.
